int_name_info: Family rewards (A Holistic Conditional Cash Transfer Program)
int_desc_ht:
['Page 10:
[¬s]"Notably, for high-school-aged students, some academic incentives
were made directly to the student rather than to their parents (e.g., the reward for passing a
Regents exam) and the other academic incentives were split between the child and their parents
(e.g., the reward for meeting the monthly attendance standard).[¬e]"', 'Page 9:
[¬s]"In Family Rewards, cash rewards were contingent upon behaviors in three areas thought to be critical to families’ and children’s short- and long-term success."
"These three areas were:
(1) education (e.g., children’s attendance in school, achievement on standardized tests, as well as
parents’ engagement with their children’s education), (2) health care (e.g., health insurance
coverage, preventive care), and (3) parents’ employment (e.g., sustaining full-time work or part-
time work plus education). Different sums of money were offered to families for each
investment they fulfilled over three years in these three areas, ranging in value from $20 to $600.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht:
['Page 9:
[¬s]"Family Rewards was an experimental, privately funded CCT
program designed to alleviate poverty and contribute to parents’ and children’s human capital
development.[¬e]"']
int_prov_ht:
['Page 2:
[¬s]"Family Rewards, launched by the Center for Economic
Opportunity in the Mayor’s Office of the City of New York in 2007 and co-designed and
evaluated by MDRC[¬e]"']
int_prov_info: "In response, New York City’s Mayor Bloomberg appointed a Commission for Economic Opportunity in 2006 comprised of leaders from the nonprofit, business, philanthropic, and academic sectors."  "MDRC is a nonprofit, nonpartisan education and social policy research organization based in New York City  Washington, DC  and Oakland and Los Angeles, CA."
int_approach_info: N/A - No teaching intervention, financial incentives intervention
parent_partic_ht:
['Page 9:
[¬s]"In Family Rewards, cash rewards were contingent upon behaviors in three areas thought
to be critical to families’ and children’s short- and long-term success. These three areas were:
(1) education (e.g., children’s attendance in school, achievement on standardized tests, as well as

parent_partic_info: Parents and children received financial incentives for meeting a set criteria. Part of this criteria included parental involvement in their children's' educations and provision of information pertaining to employment etc.
int_when_info: Payments were received yearly/monthly/per test etc. (See Table. 1, Page 53).
int_who_info: No teaching involved in this intervention. Payments were given by non-profit organisations.
int_freq_info: Variable. Payments given on monthly, yearly and per test basis etc. (See Table 1, page 53)
int_fidel_ht:
['Page 40:
[¬s]"A second limitation of the current study concerns the stage of development in the design
of CCTs for advanced, services-rich economies and societies. Family Rewards was designed
and implemented rapidly and underwent no ?pilot phase? before being submitted to a rigorous
randomized impact evaluation. As such, we wish to characterize the Family Rewards initiative
as US CCT 1.0."
"There are many design and implementation lessons about CCTs in urban 21st
Century America that MDRC has already learned in the process as they re-designed Family
Rewards for a second trial in both New York City and Memphis, Tennessee (Dechausay, Miller,
& Quiroz-Becerra, 2014). These include decisions to: offer rewards for fewer behaviors; make
the financial rewards for the reduced number of behavioral conditions larger; tie the receipt of
the rewards closer in time to the behavioral fulfillment of the conditions. It is hoped that these
and other adaptations of the Family Rewards program evaluated in the current study will increase
the effectiveness of CCTs in urban America and move it from 1.0 to 2.0.[¬e]"']

['Page 10:

(range=$50-$6,000 per year), and seventy percent of families received between $1,000-5,000 per
year (Riccio et al., 2010).[¬e]"', 'Page 42:
[¬s]"This work was supported by the Smith Richardson Foundation [Grant number 20088598] and the
William T. Grant Foundation [Grant number 10171].[¬e]"']

int_name_info: The Conditional Cash Transfer (CCT) Program in Turkey
int_desc_ht:
['Page 24:
[¬s]"Program administrators use the “proxy means testing” method to identify the poorest.
This approach relies on indicators that are highly correlated with household income (or total
consumption expenditure), yet are easy to collect, observe, and verify.[¬e]"', 'Page 27:
[¬s]"Beneficiary status should be sustained under certain conditions. Since the supports
provided by the CCT program should depend on positive behavioral changes by
beneficiaries, the maintenance of beneficiary status is based on the following conditions:
• For the children who receive the education support:
o Attend 80 percent of the total school days
o Not to repeat the same grade more than once.
• For the children who receive the health support:
o Children at 0 to 6th months require regular check-ups every month.
o Children of 7th to 18th months require regular check-ups every two
months.
o Children of 19th to 72nd months require regular check-ups every six
months.
• For the women who receive the pregnancy support:
o Regular health check-ups are required every month until the birth.
o Birth shall be given in hospital.
o Post-birth check-ups are required following the birth."
"Receipts of payments are often facilitated through the distribution of ATM cards.
Beneficiaries may receive their ATM cards from the concerned bank branches in their own
sub-provinces after signing an ATM contract form. During this process, either SYDV staff or
bank staff are supposed to help the beneficiaries who are not literate."
"Education and health support should be provided for twelve months, with bi-monthly
payments in September, November, January, March, May and July. Pregnancy support
should be provided from the second month of the pregnancy to the second month of post-
pregnancy.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 44:\n[¬s]"The CCT program’s foremost objectives are to increase school attendance rates, for\nthe poor in general and for secondary-school girls in particular, and to decrease dropout rates.[¬e]"']
int_prov_ht:
['Page 23:
[¬s]"The Social Solidarity Foundation (SYDTF)
and the Social Services and Child Protection Organization (SHCEK) were established as the
two main government institutions coping with social risk mitigation, besides municipalities,
nongovernmental organizations, such as
development foundations, and professional
associations."
"The Government of Turkey provides a number of social assistance programs aimed at
the delivery of cash and in-kind benefits and social services to individuals and families, who
are poor and to individuals with specific needs.[¬e]"', 'Page 24:
[¬s]"In order to ensure that the conditions of CCT were met by the beneficiaries, protocols
were signed between the General Directorate of Social Assistance and Solidarity (SYDGM),
the Ministry of Health (MOH) and the Ministry of Education (MOE) so that the attendance
records of CCT beneficiaries would be regularly reported by the local schools and health
centers directly to the Foundations.[¬e]"']
int_training_info: Training was provided for those conducting the survey, but not for CCTs
parent_partic_info: Parents received the CCTs and were surveyed by the investigators.
int_who_info: N/A. Teachers were responsible for teaching students, governing bodies were responsible for providing the cash transfers.
int_dur_ht:
['Page 31:
[¬s]"A large, cross-sectional household survey (see Section 3.2.1 below for
the
determination of sample size). This survey was launched in December 2005 and
completed in March 2006."
"A two-round panel survey of 750 households to be selected from eligible households
who recently (in September 2005) entered the program. The first round of the panel
survey was carried out for these 750 households simultaneously with the large
household survey. After nine months, a post-intervention panel survey will be
conducted for the same households to see the impact of the treatment on selected
outcomes.[¬e]"']
int_dur_info: 2 Surveys began 1 year after the CCT was implemented. First surveys took place over 3 months. A two-round panel survey took place, first in September 2005 and then again 9 months later

int_cost_info: $360 million was allocated to the project.  Beneficiaries received various monthly payments of 17 - 39 YTL per child based on various criteria.
comp_var_ht:
['Page 44:
[¬s]"Net enrollment rates, generally considered better indicators of educational attainment
than gross rates, are high for children at the primary (grades 1-8) education level, but quite
low at the secondary (grades 9-11) level. For the entire sample of education-beneficiaries,
about 91 percent of all children (boys and girls) aged 6-14 are enrolled in primary school. In
contrast, only 48 percent of all children aged 14-17 are enrolled in secondary school. While
boys overtake girls in terms of net enrollment at both levels of education, the gender gap is
much larger in secondary school enrollment. The patterns are similar to that evidenced by the
gross rates shown in Table 4.15.[¬e]"']

int_name_info: Unconditional Cash Transfers given to the father/mother
int_desc_ht:
['Page 14:
[¬s]"In households randomly assigned to UCTs, the mother or father received a quarterly stipend for each child. There were no requirements or conditions linked to receiving the stipend."
"the mother or father
would receive 4,000 FCFA per year distributed in quarterly payments (approximately $8.8 USD
or 4.0 percent of household per capita expenditures). For each child ages 7 to 10 (or in grades 1
to 4 in the CCT villages), the mother or father would receive 8,000 FCFA per year in quarterly
payments (approximately $17.6 USD or 8.0 percent of household per capita expenditures), while[¬e]"', 'Page 15:
[¬s]"for each child ages 11 to 15 (or in grades 5 or higher but younger than 15 in the CCT villages),
the mother or father would receive 16,000 FCFA per year in quarterly payments (approximately
$35.2 USD or 16.0 percent of household per capita expenditures).[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 15:\n[¬s]"The key question we address is whether cash transfers improve educational outcomes, such as\nenrollment, attendance, and achievement tests, of children ages 7 to 15 in recipient households.[¬e]"']
int_objec_info: To improve enrolment, attendance and achievement of children between the ages of 7 and 15.

int_desc_ht:
['Page 11:

approximately PKR 600 (equivalent to US$10) per female student.8 Beneficiary girls were
targeted based on their district of residence (districts with the lowest literacy rates in the province
– below 40 percent), and enrollment in eligible grades (grades 6 through 8) in public schools;
eligibility was conditional on a minimum school attendance rate of 80 percent, as reported
regularly by the school.[¬e]"']

int_name_ht: ['Page 8:\n[¬s]"Program Keluarga Harapan (PKH, or the Hopeful Family Program)[¬e]"']
int_desc_ht:
['Page 20:
[¬s]"Each household continues to receive their allocation in quarterly tranches as long as they meet the health and education conditions, which were specified at the beginning of the program. These conditions include the following: Households with pregnant or lactating women i. Complete four antenatal care visits and take iron tablets during pregnancy. ii. Be assisted by a trained professional during the birth. iii. Lactating mothers must complete two post-natal care visits. Households with children aged 0-6 years iv. Ensure that the children have complete childhood immunization and take Vitamin A capsules a minimum of twice a year. v. Take children for growth monitoring check-ups (monthly for infants 0-11 months, and quarterly for children 1-6 years)."
"Households with children aged 6-
15 years
vi. Enroll their children in primary school and ensure
attendance for a minimum of 85 percent of school days.
vii. Enroll junior secondary school children and ensure
attendance for a minimum of 85 percent of school days.
Households with children aged 16- viii. Enroll their children in an education program to complete 9[¬e]"', 'Page 21:
[¬s]"18 years but have not completed
nine years of primary and
secondary school
years equivalent.[¬e]"']
int_desc_info: Households received a minimum of 600,000 RP/maximum of 2,200,000 (split into quarterly instalments) as long as they met the participation criteria.
int_objec_ht:
['Page 8:
[¬s]"the program is designed to break
the transmission of poverty to next generations by encouraging families to increase their use of public
services to, over time, improve the health and education outcomes of their children.[¬e]"']
int_prov_ht: ['Page 8:\n[¬s]"In 2007, the Government of Indonesia launched its first household-based conditional cash transfer\nprogram: Program Keluarga Harapan (PKH, or the Hopeful Family Program).[¬e]"']
int_training_ht:
['Page 24:
[¬s]"Finally, personnel at
education and health service providers received too little training prior to the introduction of PKH and
were unprepared to assist in the delivery the unique outreach, intake (at the service center), and data
recording processes that the PKH program utilizes.[¬e]"']
parent_partic_info: Parents received quarterly payments in the interest in improving participation in the education district.
int_who_info: No intervention to be delivered. Payments were delivered by local district authorities.
int_dur_ht:
['Page 8:
[¬s]"A
baseline household survey in participating (treatment) and non-participating (control) kecamatan was
conducted in 2007. The same households were surveyed again in 2009, producing a full panel of data
that was used to evaluate the program’s impact.[¬e]"']
int_fidel_ht:
['Page 23:
[¬s]"As is common practice for most social assistance programs and other government-provided services in
Indonesia, socialization and advertising activities were delegated to the Ministry of Communication and
Information (Kemenkominfo). An operations engineering report, however, found that program
socialization for PKH was deficient in content, frequency, and intensity.22 Program beneficiaries did not
receive written materials and time allocated for information dissemination was limited.[¬e]"', 'Page 24:
[¬s]"Finally, personnel at
education and health service providers received too little training prior to the introduction of PKH and
were unprepared to assist in the delivery the unique outreach, intake (at the service center), and data
recording processes that the PKH program utilizes."
"During the first two years of implementation, verification of compliance and recalculation of benefits
were not fully operational. As a result, there were few – if any – penalties for non-compliant
households. Most households continued to receive their initial allocations; the actual average annual
payments per household did not decrease over the three-year pilot evaluation period (Table 3.1). There
are indications, however, that beneficiary households were aware of the threat of losing full payment in
areas where facilitators made extra efforts to inform them about the consequences of non-compliance.
In remote areas, however, facilitators reportedly spent more time traveling and completing their
administrative responsibilities, than working directly with families and informing them about program
expectations.27[¬e]"']
int_cost_info: See Table 3.1 (Page 24) for details of average PKH Payments Average payment per year per household  1,208,967(Rp)
